awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Open Core Data: Transformative Data Infrastructure for Integrating and Accessing Scientific Drilling and Coring Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientific drilling and coring is crucial for the advancement of the Earth Sciences. Vast
resources have been invested in drilling and coring operations around the world: on land,
in the oceans, and in the polar regions. The return of these investments must be maximized
by ensuring optimal access and re-usability of the data generated through drilling and coring
projects.

This project, Open Core Data (OCD), is a next-generation approach to data management that will
open vast stores of existing and future geoscience data to new and innovative scientific use by
radically improving discoverability, accessibility, citability, preservation, and integration
of data from past, current, and future drilling and coring projects.

Research objectives of the International Ocean Discovery Program and Continental
Scientific Drilling communities provide impressive examples of the breadth of scientific
themes that drilling and coring helps address, ranging from the nature of the deep biosphere
and oceanic sub-seafloor, to understanding environmental change, species evolution, fault
zone dynamics, magmatism, and tectonics, among many others. The scientific potential enabled
by OCD is therefore large and expected to impact many geoscience domains. OCD will form the
nucleus of a federated data infrastructure that will support entirely new scientific approaches
and lines of inquiry by facilitating integration of continental and marine data for synthesis
studies.

OCD will align with NSF data policies to provide open access to all scientific drilling data.
Both research and the process of transferring data to archives for permanent curation will
be simplified and streamlined through this effort. Open Core Data will structure and integrate
scientific drilling data optimally to enable data-driven science that faces substantial barriers
at present related to data heterogeneity in discovery, access, and formats. Open Core Data
will enable geoscience domains that utilize scientific drilling and coring in their workflows
to come closer to realizing the full potential of their data, and to make their own unique
new contributions that benefit science and society as new research is enabled.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This award funded the processes required to flow data from past, ongoing, and future scientific drilling projects from the Continental Scientific Drilling Facility to a data system called Open Core Data. This new system, developed by partner institutions through their own collaborative awards, aimed to serve as a centralized clearinghouse for data generated in the course of scientific research projects including site survey data, performance data describing the drilling or coring process, borehole geophysical survey data, core logs (visual lithologic descriptions), core photographs, several types of automated core scans, and registration of core samples to allow unpublished core scanning data to be linked to published analytical data. Enhanced and hosted at Open Core Data, these datasets would achieve the goals of being maximally Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable – abbreviated as the FAIR data principles, widely viewed as the leading goal for scientific data. Leveraging common data types, the system aimed to support other facilities and communities generating similar samples and data types, including marine coring and drilling communities.

The work funded by the award to the University of Minnesota involves the preparation of data, workflows, and processes to allow existing and new data to flow to the new data system, specifically:

  1. Developing a comprehensive knowledge of workflows, data types, instrumentation, and data processing related to generation of fundamental metadata and analytical datasets in scientific drilling projects.
  2. Coordinating refinement of metadata requirements and revision of protocols.
  3. Providing formatting and quality checks on scientific drilling data and metadata.
  4. Uploading scientific drilling data and metadata to Open Core Data.
  5. Collaboration with Open Core Data developers to refine workflows, user interfaces,
    and necessary linkages for routine upload of new datasets generated at the Continental Scientific Drilling Facility to Open Core Data.

These tasks set for the University of Minnesota were completed successfully. The team developed data dictionaries for the data types produced during scientific drilling projects; standardized formats for each data type; identified and (whenever possible) filled gaps in workflows and systems that comprise the necessary data flows. Existing and new scientific drilling data and metadata generated at the Continental Scientific Drilling Facility are now aligned for consumption by other data systems. All datasets no longer in access moratorium are available through Open Core Data. Key priorities have been identified for directing ongoing and future efforts to enhance data systems that accomplish the original aims of the project, to make scientific drilling data findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable. 

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2022
Modified by: Anders J Noren
